Why should I believe anything? Any claim/belief you give me I can ask you to justify it. And when you give me a claim that is supposed to justify that previous claim I can ask what justifies this new claim. You can either give me justifications forever, go in a circle, or just dogmatically assert that some claims are true but do not need justification.

values: How do you know there is such a thing as consciousness? Couldn't both consciousness and mental states be illusions, and matter be the only thing that exists?

values.text: You brought up an argument from Anthony Quinton's "The Soul"(1962): "A more usual argument for the principle starts from the premise that mental states are acts that cannot be conceived without an agent in the same way as there cannot be a blow without a striker or a journey without a traveler. The premise of this argument has been much criticized by recent philosophers. A feeling of depression or a belief in the trust- worthiness of a friend is not a precisely datable occurrence but a more or less persisting dispositional state. Nor is it an instance of agency in the sense of being the intentional execution of a decision. But these mistaken implications do not affect the validity of the argument under consideration. A disposition requires a possessor as much as an act requires an agent, and the blow I get from a swinging door still presupposes the existence of the door even though it did not mean to hit me."
Alright, but why should I believe there are mental states? Couldn't both consciousness and mental states be illusions, and matter be the only thing that exists?
